node.title: Albums of the decade 2010 -2019
node.content:
Another decade has passed and the future has officially arrived – 2020 occurs one year later than the period of original Blade Runner’s world. In terms of music, 2010-2019 was one of the best decades. In terms of private life, it was one of the most beautiful and the hardest periods in which I experienced the greatest love and got through the greatest of pains.

The decade began in a slightly sad and melancholic tone. I listened to Massive Attack’s Heligoland during the winter 2010 while receiving an antibiotic therapy – and this was the overall feel of that year: cold, sad and lonely. The next two years were alright, but nothing seemed to be as it should. As I remember, there was that winter feel all over. I guess listening to Kate Bush’s 50 Words For Snow helped maintain that feeling.

The Black Keys where a leftover from a previous life, while Tame Impala lead me into modern psychedelic rock. I listened to Melody’s Echo Chamber while learning French and Kurt Vile’s Walking On A Pretty Daze took me to sunny places.

I met the love of my life on Zdravo Mladi Festival. We talked about The Soft Moon’s performance at the festival and stayed together for the whole night (and we’ve been together ever since). In 2015, he played me Birds of passage and her nocturnal music took the form of the pain that I carried inside me. In 2016, we saw Föllakzoid and Moon Duo playing at the same festival. The following year, there was Slowdive. In the recent years, the festival’s programme began to cater the tastes in music embraced by younger generations, so we lost interest.

2017 was definitely the year of King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard and the sweet discovery of Australia’s music scene. 2018 was the year of psychedelic (guitar) music coming from all corners of the world: Wooden Shjips, The Babe Rainbow, Kikagaku Mojo, Minami Deutsch. The re-listening to Dead can Dance’s catalog represented a rediscovery of a new, long forgotten world.

2019 was an year of calmness and introspection, setting life priorities straight and greater restriction of the things that I let occupy my time and mental space. Tranquility and harmony, backed up by ambient music that was played by, well, you know who. The event of the year was the Dead can Dance’s concert in Budapest. Last minute tickets secured us places in the last row of a gargantuan sports arena. Yet, all of that was insignificant in comparison to the beauty of the sonic spectacle provided by Lisa and Brendan who marked their thirty-ninth anniversary of the band’s existence.

This is the list of the most listened to records of the last decade:

2010

  • Massive Attack – Heligoland (2010)
  • The National – High Violet (2010)
  • Grinderman – Grinderman 2 (2010)

2011

  • PJ Harvey – Let England Shake (2011)
  • Kate Bush – 50 Words for Snow (2011)
  • Bill Callahan – Apocalypse (2011)
  • Radiohead – The King of Limbs (2011)
  • Little Dragon – Ritual Union (2011)

2012

  • The Black Keys – Brothers (2010)
  • The Black Keys – El Camino (2011)
  • Tindersticks – The Something Rain (2012)
  • Wild Nothing – Nocturne (2012)
  • Cat Power – Sun (2012)
  • Bat For Lashes – The Haunted Man (2012)

2013

  • Tame Impala – Innerspeaker (2010)
  • Tame Impala – Lonerism (2012)
  • Melody’s Echo Chamber – Melody’s Echo Chamber (2012)
  • Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds – Push the sky away (2013)
  • Daughter – If you leave (2013)
  • Rhye – Woman (2013)

2014

  • The Soft Moon – The Soft Moon (2010)
  • Darkside (Nicolas Jaar) – Psychic (2013)
  • Kurt Vile – Walking on a pretty daze (2013)

2015

  • Grouper – AIA: Alien Observer (2011)
  • Dawn of Midi – Dysomnia (2013)
  • Birds of Passage – This Kindly Slumber (2014)
  • Tame Impala – Currents (2015)
  • A Place to Bury Strangers – Transfixiation (2015)

2016

  • Moon Duo – Circles (2012)
  • Föllakzoid – II (2013)
  • Cosmonauts – Persona Non Grata (2013)
  • Kreidler – ABC (2014)
  • Holy Wave – Relax (2014)
  • Föllakzoid – III (2015)
  • New Candys – New Candys As Medicine (2015)
  • Cosmonauts – A-OK (2016)

2017

  • OM – Advaitic Songs (2012)
  • Cave – Threace (2013)
  • King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard – Quarters (2015)
  • SUUNS – Hold/Still (2016)
  • K-X-P – III, Pt.1 (2016)
  • Moon Duo – Occult Architecture (2017)
  • King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard – Flying Microtonal Banana (2017), Polygonwannaland (2017), Sketches of Brunswick East (2017)
  • Slowdive – Slowdive (2017)

2018

  • Wooden Shjips – Back to Land (2013)
  • Minami Deutsch – Minami Deutsch (2014)
  • The Babe Rainbow – The Babe Rainbow (2015)
  • Naxatras – Naxatras (2015)
  • Unknown Mortal Orchestra – Multi-love (2015)
  • Kikagaku Moyo – House in the Tall Grass (2016)
  • King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard – Gumboot Soup (2017)
  • Biblical – The City That Always Sleeps (2017)
  • Dead Can Dance – Dionysus (2018)
  • Wooden Shjips – V (2018)
  • The Babe Rainbow – Double Rainbow (2018)
  • Kikagaku Moyo – Masana Temples (2018)
  • Minami Deutsch – With Dim Light (2018)
  • Dungen/Woods – Myths 003 (2018)
  • Triptides – Visitors (2018)
  • Hookworms – Microshift (2018)
  • Mild Orange – Foreplay (2018)

2019

  • Gaussian Curve – Impossible Island (2015)
  • Juana Molina – Halo (2017)
  • Skinshape – Filoxiny (2018)
  • Beak> – >>> (2018)
  • Claypool Lennon Delirium – South of Reality (2019)
  • Moon Duo – Stars are the Light (2019)
  • DIIV – Deceiver (2019)
node.excerpt: Another decade has passed and the future has officially arrived – 2020 occurs one year later than the period of original Blade Runner’s world. In terms of music, 2010-2019 was one of the best decades. In terms of private life, it was one of the most beautiful and the hardest periods in which I experienced the greatest love and got through the greatest of pains….

node.title: Past, Present and Yet To Come: The music of 2018
node.content:
It is amazing how easily I got used to the new year and 2018 already seams so far away. Throughout December I was thinking back to the year that passed by, but I got the festive blues and couldn’t find the strength to summarize it. On Christmas Eve I gathered my thoughts and, just like in the Christmas Carol, I let the Ghosts of the Past, the Present and the Yet To Come to remind me on what was before, how is it now and what the future might be.

Past

I spent large portion of 2018 with the music of Kate Bush. I cannot even explain myself what kind of a force is it that drags me towards her, but her music simply enchants me. Hearing her saying „Take my shoes off/ and throw them in the lake“, I literally feel the urge to throw my shoes and simply start walking wherever my feet may take me. I mostly listened to The Sensual World, Hounds of Love and Aerial.

Smashing Pumpkins were a big deal for me back in the ‘90s, spending hours and hours listening to Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness, Siamese Dream and Pisces Iscariot. Yet, their debut album Gish remained quite unfamiliar, so this year I went back to correct that.

Gish has the unfortunate destiny to be constantly compared, and thus overshadowed, by Nirvana’s Nevermind, both produced by Butch Vig (Garbage) and released the same year of 1991. Unlike Nirvana, Smashing Pumpkins did not gain much of a fame and fortune at that time, but merely appeared on the scene and announced their presence. However, the following years they took over the alternative rock music scene and marked the music of the ‘90s. This year The Smashing Pumpkins made a come-back with a new album and a tour named “Shiny And Oh So Bright” which I gladly awaited. But, I regret to state that these Smashing Pumpkins are some faded away version of that once cool band from the ‘90s. They had it, they lost it.

This year marks 20 years from the releasing of Air’s debut album Moon Safari. All these years I’ve never stopped listening to this album and I’ve never ever got bored of it. Being unpretentious and modest, it is a unique masterpiece combining electronic music, jazz, synth-pop, space-rock and trip-hop with a French twist.

Reading the memoir “Drugs are nice” by Lisa Crystal Carver (Lisa Suckdog), a former partner of Bill Callahan, led me to re-listen his 2011 album Apocalypse. I love it how the sound on this album is so crisp and clear that I have the feeling I can almost touch it.

From the memoir one could get the picture for the most obscure underground scene of the ‘80s and early ‘90s, various experimental and noise rock musicians, performance artists and complete lunatics like GG Allin, which were Lisa’s friends. I couldn’t understand how could the eccentric Lisa and the quiet Bill ever get along. She wanted to become famous, and Bill didn’t have much of ambitions. From today’s perspective, they both achieved the totally opposite.

Present

During January we had the time to listen to King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard’s Gumboot Soup which came out at the very end of 2017. The alternative Australian scene was a sweet discovery, but the music coming from Japan was even more exotic. The psychedelic and kraut rock music of Japanese bands Kikagaku Moyo and Minami Deutch and their 2018 albums Masana Temples and With Dim Light respectively were one of the most listened throughout 2018.

The summer was marked by psychedelic rock listening to Wooden Shjips, Double Rainbow and Triptides. We saw Wooden Shjips at Zdravo Mladi Festival in September and the good old San-Fran hippies took us on a ride to the psychedelic landscapes of their music. Their melodies are crazy enough to be fun, but carefully dosed not to be heavy to digest.

At the beginning of December Dead Can Dance released their latest album Dionysus, which consists of seven songs divided in two parts named Act I and Act II and it covers different aspects of the myth of the ancient god Dionysus. The music on the album has this specific Balkan melody while the band was using instruments from all over the world.

There is something primordial in the music of Dead Can Dance which I recognize as something that belongs to me, like some long forgotten part of myself. I immediately fell in love with this album.

Yet To Come

I wrongfully ignored the Ghost of the Yet To Come and didn’t assume that he could bring me another loss of a loved one at the very beginning of the year. For better or worse, once faced with a great loss in life, one learns how to deal with future pains of such scale. It doesn’t get easier, but you nevertheless learn.

I want to believe in the philosophy of the Tralfamadorians from Kurt Vonnegut’s Slaughterhouse-Five who perceive time as a whole and the destiny of every human as an eternal present. According to them, when someone dies, it just seems so, because one is still alive in the past.

I like that idea. It gives me comfort and soothes me.
